title: ERC-1726: Dividend-Paying Token Standard

body: I'm interested in this- is this the only/best dividend token design?

I'm having a hard time understanding what the difference is between

`function dividendOf(address _owner) external view returns(uint256);`

and

`function withdrawableDividendOf(address _owner) external view returns(uint256);`

especially since one just calls the other in your implementation

> I'm interested in this- is this the only/best dividend token design?

Hi, @jtremback 
Good to know that you are interested!

I think you are referring to our implementation of a dividend-paying token rather than the interface design of it.
It's of course not the only implementation of such tokens, but we think it's a good enough one in most use cases.
It costs the same amount of gas to distribute and withdraw dividends no matter how many token holders there are.
And the error between the actual value and the ideal value of a dividend is only several weis.

We are not the one who invented this dividend distribution mechanism.
We first saw it in [the PoWH3D token contract](https://etherscan.io/address/0xB3775fB83F7D12A36E0475aBdD1FCA35c091efBe#code).
We re-wrote it to make it cleaner and more reusable.

> I'm having a hard time understanding what the difference is between
> 
> `function dividendOf(address _owner) external view returns(uint256);`
> 
> and
> 
> `function withdrawableDividendOf(address _owner) external view returns(uint256);`
> 
> especially since one just calls the other in your implementation

Yes, they actually do the same thing.

We think that `dividendOf` may be ambiguous.
Some may think it means "all the dividends you've got", including the withdrawn part and the not-yet-withdrawn part, while some think it's only the not-yet-withdrawn part.
That's why we added the three OPTIONAL viewing functions to make it more unambiguous.

We definitely need more suggestions from the community about the namings.
Please leave a comment if you have any!
Hi Roger, is there a special reason why you chose 2**64 as magnitude in the implementation?

> We first saw it in [the PoWH3D token contract](https://etherscan.io/address/0xB3775fB83F7D12A36E0475aBdD1FCA35c091efBe#code).

Here's some additional foundational work for this appraoch: https://medium.com/@weka/dividend-bearing-tokens-on-ethereum-42d01c710657 by @Arachnid

> Hi Roger, is there a special reason why you chose 2**64 as magnitude in the implementation?

### Short Answer

We simply followed what PoWH3D did.
Something between 2\**128 and 2\**165 may be a better choice for `magnitude`.

### Long Answer

In this implementation, the constraints of `magnitude` is made by these lines:

```solidity
magnifiedDividendPerShare = magnifiedDividendPerShare.add(
  (msg.value).mul(magnitude) / totalSupply()
);

```

```solidity
function accumulativeDividendOf(address _owner) public view returns(uint256) {
  return magnifiedDividendPerShare.mul(balanceOf(_owner)).toInt256Safe()
    .add(magnifiedDividendCorrections[_owner]).toUint256Safe() / magnitude;
}
```

We want
1. `(msg.value).mul(magnitude)` never overflows.
1. `magnifiedDividendPerShare` never overflows.
1. `magnifiedDividendPerShare.mul(balanceOf(_owner)).toInt256Safe()` never overflows.
1. the remainder of `(msg.value).mul(magnitude) / totalSupply()` is as small as possible compared to `magnitude`.

To sum up, we want to maximize `magnitude` while `(total received ether in wei) * magnitude < 2**255`.

Say, if we know that we will never receive > 1 billion ETH, or about 2\**90 wei, then 2\**165 is a good choice for `magnitude`.
renamed `payAndDistributeDividends` to `distributeDividends`

Did this ever get turned into an official Draft EIP or no?
No.
@Roger-Wu currently this only works for ETH, is there any possibility this can be used with erc20 token?

we made [this](https://github.com/atpar/funds-distribution-token/blob/master/contracts/extensions/FDT_ERC20Extension.sol) a while ago which is closely aligned with EIP-1726. which is part of a reference implementation of [EIP-2222](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/2222). though keep in mind that all of this code is unaudited and outdated.

There has been no activity on this issue for two months. It will be closed in a week if no further activity occurs. If you would like to move this EIP forward, please respond to any outstanding feedback or add a comment indicating that you have addressed all required feedback and are ready for a review.
Hello Roger, if manually send ether to the contract, withdrawableDividendOf will increase?
If continued discussion about this idea is desired, it should be moved to Ethereum Magicians forum or a formal EIP draft should be created.
essa soluçao tambem pode ser usada em blockhain da binance

> essa soluçao tambem pode ser usada em blockhain da binance




The BSC blockchain is based on Ethereum's EVM. So yes, the code syntax and logic works.

I have published a modification (updated to Solidity 0.8.1) to be able to share ERC20 tokens as dividends, instead of native tokens:
https://github.com/Alexander-Herranz/ERC20DividendPayingToken

Feel free to leave you comments or PR any improvement.
